text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.4.12, Case Processing, Field Office Resource Team (FORT).
Incorporated IPU 16U0900 issued 05/11/2016 and IPU 14U0036 issued 1/6/2014 in IRM 5.4.12.2.5 (4) and (5) increasing cycle time from four to eight cycles.
Updated IRM 5.4.12.2.2, eliminating deﬁnition of the Taxpayer Advocate Service, and additional clariﬁcation for working Operations Assistance Requests
Editorial changes have been made throughout.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 5.4.12, dated 12/18/2013 and incorporates IPU 14U0036, Increase Cycle Time, issued 1/6/2014, and IPU 16U0900, Revalidating IPU 14U0036 to Change Cycle Time, issued 05/11/2016.
Centralized Case Processing FORT team in the Philadelphia Campus

Resource Team

) The Field Office Resource Team (FORT) was created to provide a link between Centralized Case Processing (CCP) and Collection Field function (CFf) for the resolution of workﬂow issues, technical assistance, and general and procedural questions. The FORT will also provide support to process cases, and perform data analysis for continuous process improve- ments in CCP and CFf. (

) The primary purpose and responsibilities of the FORT in CCP is to provide: a. Liaison services for IRS agencies. b. Case Processing Support for internal customers. c. Data Analysis for CCP. d. Customer Service to SBSE ﬁeld, taxpayers, and CCP. (
) This section describes the type of work the FORT will perform. (
) General Case Processing (GCP) and Manually Monitored Installment Agreement (MMIA) departments will prepare a referral to the FORT for beyond their scope. Local procedures and IRM
will determine the method and forms used to make the referrals. Note: If the FORT referral does not meet IRM
criteria reject the referral back the originator. (
) The FORT will assign and open a control base on IDRS within
days of receipt of case. Note: All FORT referrals require IDRS or the Integrated Collection System (ICS) Accounts Management System (AMS) to be documented as appropriate. (
) Unless otherwise indicated in this IRM, the FORT has
days from receipt the case to take necessary action. (

) The Field Office Resource Team (FORT) was created to provide a link between Centralized Case Processing (CCP) and Collection Field (CFf) for the resolution of workﬂow issues, technical assistance, and general and procedural questions. The FORT will also provide support to process cases, and perform data analysis for continuous process ments in CCP and CFf. (

) The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act,
U.S.C. app. Section

, provides deferment of payment of taxes by individuals whose ability to pay has been “materially affected” by the individuals military service. The deferment applies to the period of qualiﬁed military service plus a maximum of
days after service period ends. (
) IRM
and IRM
deﬁne the criteria for taxpayers to qualify for military deferment. The FORT is responsible to monitor all military deferment cases in Status

Combat Zone cases are a category of military deferment and are NOT monitored in Centralized Case Processing. The cases are to be maintained until the military deferment period has expired. Upon receipt of a military deferment case check IDRS for the following: a. Posting of Status
b. Posting of TC
CC
(prior to Jan.
) and CC

(after Jan. on all balance due modules. If not posted, do the input, making sure to the liability indicator P for Primary, S for Spouse, or B for Both. c. The tax examiner is to verify that the military deferment expiration date is computed correctly. Military Deferment expiration equals taxpayer’s requested period of deferment during qualiﬁed military service plus
5.4.12.2.3 (11-30-2016) Military Deferment

IRM 5.1.7.12 and IRM 5.19.1.4.9 deﬁne the criteria for taxpayers to qualify military deferment. The FORT is responsible to monitor all military deferment cases in Status 26. Combat Zone cases are a category of military deferment and are NOT monitored in Centralized Case Processing. The cases are to be maintained until the military deferment period has expired. Upon receipt of a military deferment case check IDRS for the following:
b. Posting of TC
CC
(prior to Jan.
) and CC
(after Jan.

) on all balance due modules. If not posted, do the input, making sure to put the liability indicator P for Primary, S for Spouse, or B for Both. c. The tax examiner is to verify that the military deferment expiration date is computed correctly. Military Deferment expiration equals taxpayer’s requested period of deferment during qualiﬁed military service plus
days.
See IRM
and IRM

for a description of the periods of military service that qualify for deferment. If the military deferment expira- tion date is not correct, establish the correct date and use the corrected date throughout the procedures. d. Check IDRS (SUMRY and IMFOLI) to conﬁrm all tax returns have been ﬁled. If the taxpayer is not in ﬁling compliance (all income tax returns ﬁled), ask the taxpayer to submit the unﬁled returns. Failure to submit unﬁled returns does not prevent a taxpayer from being eligible for military deferment. e. Conﬁrm that the taxpayer’s adjusted gross income (AGI) has decreased from the prior year compared to the start date of the military deferment. This should be indicated on the Letter
C, Collection Postponed Initial Period of Active Military Service, or equivalent statement. If it has not decreased then the taxpayer is generally not eligible for military deferment.

Case Note: Current monthly expenses incurred by the taxpayer as a result of military service should be deducted if current monthly earned income is more than monthly earned income immediately prior to military service. See IRM
and IRM
for detailed instructions for deter- mining eligibility for military deferment. f. Documentation as outlined in IRM
must be in the case ﬁle. (
) If the taxpayer does not qualify for military deferment reject the case to the originator. See IRM
) to determine if the taxpayer qualiﬁes for reduced interest rate. (

) After verifying that the taxpayer qualiﬁes for military deferment and the above information, take the following actions to monitor the case: a. Create the case on ICS if not already created. b. Document ICS with receipt of case and actions taken, as well as the culated deferment date. c. Establish follow-up date. Determine this date by subtracting
days the deferment date. (

) Review the case when the scheduled follow-up date arrives (via ICS notiﬁca- tion); review IDRS to determine current status of case. If case status has changed, such as full payment received or status has changed to
(installment agreement), no action is needed. If deferment period has expired, close the OI. Note: Because accruals were suspended per the TC
it may be necessary to manually compute interest and FTP penalty. See IRM

for FTP penalty instructions. (

by end of the
day suspense period, transfer the case and forward the paper case ﬁle to the appropriate lection function. (
) If taxpayer responds to Letter

take the following actions: a. If the taxpayer responds with full payment and is in full compliance, forward case to closed case ﬁles and close ICS control. b. If taxpayer requests an installment agreement, input a TC
AC
c. If the taxpayer’s response indicates an inability to full pay, but the wants to explore other payment options, determine if taxpayer qualiﬁes guaranteed or streamlined IA. Follow procedures in IRM

d. If the taxpayer’s response indicates inability to pay, secure a Collection Information Statement (CIS) and determine if the account meets criteria for Currently Not Collectable (CNC) Hardship. If they do not meet CNC criteria contact taxpayer for appropriate case resolution. (

) When conducting a two-year review, consider the taxpayer’s income, Installment expenses, assets and equity to determine if: a. The balance due can be full paid, or; b. an adjustment to the payment amount is necessary, or; c. the agreement should continue without change, or; d. the taxpayer is unable to pay. (

) Lockbox requests are taxpayer payments on current installment agreements other balance dues. When the taxpayer sends the payment to the IRS without a payment voucher or there is insufficient information for the vendor determine the correct posting of the payment, the vendor will fax these requests to the FORT daily. FORT TE’s will research IDRS to determine correct posting of the remittance. Lockbox requests must be completed and returned to the vendor via fax within
hours of receipt. Completed requests will be held in a suspense ﬁle for one week and then should be purged. (

hours of receipt. Completed requests will be held in a suspense ﬁle for one week and then should be purged.

) When Criminal Investigation (CI) conducts an investigation on a taxpayer assigned to a revenue officer, civil enforcement action may be temporarily suspended in order to allow the CI investigation to proceed. A Transaction Code (TC)
is placed on these accounts. CCP will monitor balance due delinquent return cases. A TC

should appear on all modules showing a delinquency before the case is transferred. The purpose of monitoring TC is to: a. Address and protect CSED/ASED issues. b. Ensure two-year risk analysis (e.g., collectibility determination, noncompliance, status of CI investigation) and lien reﬁling is conducted required. c. Monitor the ICS case for completion of the CI activity and reassignment the ﬁeld if required. d. Address new balance due modules that need TC
input or parallel vestigation. (

When Criminal Investigation (CI) conducts an investigation on a taxpayer assigned to a revenue officer, civil enforcement action may be temporarily suspended in order to allow the CI investigation to proceed. A Transaction Code (TC)
is placed on these accounts. CCP will monitor balance due and delinquent return cases. A TC
should appear on all modules showing a delinquency before the case is transferred. The purpose of monitoring TC

is to: a. Address and protect CSED/ASED issues. b. Ensure two-year risk analysis (e.g., collectibility determination, continued noncompliance, status of CI investigation) and lien reﬁling is conducted as required. c. Monitor the ICS case for completion of the CI activity and reassignment to the ﬁeld if required. d. Address new balance due modules that need TC
input or parallel in- vestigation. Cases will be received from revenue officers by paper ﬁles and as ICS cases.

When Criminal Investigation (CI) conducts an investigation on a taxpayer assigned to a revenue officer, civil enforcement action may be temporarily suspended in order to allow the CI investigation to proceed. A Transaction Code (TC)

Non Master File (NMF) Cases - CI cases with 914 controls that are NMF require a TC 470, CC 90 to move the module into ST 89 (in lieu of ST 91) for monitoring. This action is completed via a Form 3177 and is sent or faxed to the CSC campus. The ST 89 will remain on the module as long as the TC 914 control is open. The Form 3177 should include a history that can be placed on the NMF case.
The following cases should not be transferred to CCP for monitoring:
Cases where the Assessment Statute Date (ASED) or Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) will expire within twelve (12) months

If an ATAT case is transferred to CCP for monitoring, special instructions must be provided to CCP FORT to ensure that any OIs issued by CCP are issued the referring ATAT revenue officer, or the appropriate Collection ATAT tor if the ATAT revenue officer is no longer assigned to the case.
